ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We watched videos and listened to poetry readings.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed skills in literary analysis; how to read a book deeply and make a rigorous argument about the text. I also learnt how to talk about literature in a group, and pick up on subtle details of a text.
I learned about a segment of american literature and found a few authors I enjoy and intend to read more about.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths were Prof Hammer's incredibly dedicated teaching style and deep knowledge about the literature and poetry of the course. Hammer would meet with my about every paper and give insightful advice and criticism. The feedback was excellent, and the class is very well organized. He also adjusted the course to our needsI can't stress this enough, when other professors were demanding we meet impossible deadlines, Hammer was making sure we weren't over worked and could commit to doing our best work under difficult circumstances. A legend. One weakness was that the discussion could get a bit into the weeds, and often ended up with him talking at us rather than. cultivating conversation. But he's a brilliant analyst so even that was enjoyable.
I wish things like civil war poetry and the declaration of independence were removed (as usually covered in earlier courses) in favor of more contemporary and diverse authors and works.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Hammer used other media forms to keep us engaged, sharing his screen and plying audio recordings from time to time. This succeeded in making class more interesting.

I wish the seminar was led by students and allowed them more time to discuss in smaller groups. I think there was too much lecturing and laying out of the material instead of allowing the class to naturally follow.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Hammer is an amazing teacher! He has so much respect for his students and engages everyone in discussions, while also conveying his enthusiasm and passion for English. The class always had a trajectory but it felt like it originated in our thoughts which shows how much he values his students. Professor Hammer's investment in class, office hours, and over email put him as one of the best teachers I've ever had. The syllabus itself was great in that I got to read important works of American Lit and appreciate them without it feeling like a survey course. Plus there's a good combination of poetry and prose. I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the subject and, more importantly, willing to invest in the class. The level of work is scalable based on how much you invest (though it's certainly not a gut), but you won't get much out of it unless you come to class ready to engage in discussion.

YES! Take 127 with Professor Hammer, he will make it an enjoyable, not overly-taxing and incredibly insightful experience. He's done this course so many times he has it organized to perfection, he knows the texts back to front, he gives excellent feedback, and he truly cared about his students growth and well-being.
I would only take this course if it is a requirement for your major. Otherwise, there are much more interesting courses with much much syllabi out there.
